title: Did inspector’s death avert full-fledged communal riots?
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Yogi Adityanath,UP violence,UP mob violence,Bulandshahr violence,bulandshahr
content: LUCKNOW: The timing, location and circumstances that led toBulandshahr violencewere in fact a perfect recipe for a communal riot big enough to make international headlines but the death of inspector Subodh Kumar Singh in mob violence prevented flare-up of further violence as the mob panicked and dispersed, feel senior police officers.“The police officer’s death apparently made the mob realise the gravity of situation and those indulging in violence and arson panicked and dispersed. There could have been the fear that police could turn aggressive after a colleague’s death,” said a senior police officer. “In a way, even while inspector Subodh died in the line of duty, his death eventually averted what could have been a much bigger tragedy,” he added.Read Also: Bulandshahr carcass was 2 days old, says UP PoliceThe site from where the cow carcasses were recovered on Monday morning — Mahav village — seems to have been meticulously chosen, raising doubts in the mind of investigators about the possibilities of a bigger conspiracy.The village is barely 500 metres away from the local police outpost under Syana police circle which is a communally sensitive region and was under a month-long curfew following a major communal riots that broke out in Khurja town of the district in early 1990s.Read Also: Will ask CM to act against hate-mongers, Cop’s sonMoreover, Mahav’s adjoining villages Chingrawti and Baans Kala are reportedly dominated by a particular community. Not only this, the road on which the police outpost is situated was to be used by thousands of people returning from a religious congregation at Dariyapur on their way to Rampur, Bareilly, Moradabad and Lucknow. The road leads to Delhi-Moradabad highway.After violence broke out, police were quick to set up holding areas on the route and divert traffic from the congregation which was attended by lakhs.The state government has also acknowledged that the violence was ‘part of a larger conspiracy’ and in a late night review meeting held on Tuesday, chief ministerYogi Adityanathdirected Director General of Police (DGP) O P Singh to trace the conspirators and perpetrators and take stringent action against them.“How did the carcasses reach the site from where they were recovered and who was behind this is also a major focus of the probe,” the DGP said on Wednesday.The investigators were also puzzled by the fact that why would anyone slaughter cows in an open field unless mischief was the motive. Sources, however, said that slaughter of cows was nothing new in the region. Recently, a major protest against cow slaughter was held outside same police outpost which was attacked by mob during Monday’s violence.“The site is also important because of its proximity to the national capital. In case a full-fledged riot had taken place, the violence would have caught the attention of national and international media,” said a senior police officer.

title: Bulandshahr violence: Did inspector’s death avert full-fledged communal riots?
keywords: Lucknow news, Lucknow latest news, Lucknow news live, Lucknow news today, Today news Lucknow, Subodh Kumar Singh,inspector,death,communal,Bulandshahr violence,bulandshahr
content: LUCKNOW: The timing, location and circumstances that led toBulandshahr violencewere in fact a perfect recipe for acommunalriot big enough to make international headlines but the death of inspectorSubodh Kumar Singhin mob violence prevented flare-up of further violence as the mob panicked and dispersed, feel senior police officers.“The police officer’s death apparently made the mob realise the gravity of situation and those indulging in violence and arson panicked and dispersed. There could have been the fear that police could turn aggressive after a colleague’s death,” said a senior police officer. “In a way, even whileinspectorSubodh died in the line of duty, his death eventually averted what could have been a much bigger tragedy,” he added.The site from where the cow carcasses were recovered on Monday morning — Mahav village — seems to have been meticulously chosen, raising doubts in the mind of investigators about the possibilities of a bigger conspiracy.The village is barely 500 metres away from the local police outpost under Syana police circle which is a communally sensitive region and was under a month-long curfew following a major communal riots that broke out in Khurja town of the district in early 1990s.Moreover, Mahav’s adjoining villages Chingrawti and Baans Kala are reportedly dominated by a particular community. Not only this, the road on which the police outpost is situated was to be used by thousands of people returning from a religious congregation at Dariyapur on their way to Rampur, Bareilly, Moradabad and Lucknow. The road leads to Delhi-Moradabad highway.After violence broke out, police were quick to set up holding areas on the route and divert traffic from the congregation which was attended by lakhs.The state government has also acknowledged that the violence was ‘part of a larger conspiracy’ and in a late night review meeting held on Tuesday, chief minister Yogi Adityanath directed Director General of Police (DGP) O P Singh to trace the conspirators and perpetrators and take stringent action against them.“How did the carcasses reach the site from where they were recovered and who was behind this is also a major focus of the probe,” the DGP said on Wednesday.The investigators were also puzzled by the fact that why would anyone slaughter cows in an open field unless mischief was the motive. Sources, however, said that slaughter of cows was nothing new in the region. Recently, a major protest against cow slaughter was held outside same police outpost which was attacked by mob during Monday’s violence.“The site is also important because of its proximity to the national capital. In case a full-fledged riot had taken place, the violence would have caught the attention of national and international media,” said a senior police officer.

title: Abhimanyu Mukherjee promises a laugh riot in his next
keywords: teko,Srabanti Chatterjee,Soham Chakraborty,Kanchan Mullick,darshana banik,Biswanath Basu,Abhimanyu Mukherjee
content: Since his directorial debut ‘Noor Jahan’ earlier this yearAbhimanyu Mukherjeehas his hand full of exciting projects. While the young director is at present busy with shooting a social satire ‘Teko’, he has another comedy caper lined up which starsSrabanti Chatterjee,Soham Chakraborty, Om Sahani,Kanchan Mullick,Biswanath Basu,Darshana Banikand Subhasish Mukherjee among others.It will simply be a laugh riot, don’t seek any serious social message – Abhimanyu has already made it clear. “It’s a hilarious comedy, beginning from the very first scene. Frankly speaking, you don’t need to invest too much thought in the film. Neither there’s any social message. We just want the audience to visit the hall, laugh a lot and go home,” said the director.Interestingly, in his last film ‘Piya Re’ also Abhimanyu had Soham Chakraborty and Srabanti Chatterjee in the lead. While the film he is currently shooting, stars Ritiwick Chakraborty and Srabanti in the lead.Young actress Darshana Banik who plays a middle-class girl from North Kolkata is excited to work with a bunch of experienced actors: “I always wanted to work in a commercial film. I am thankful to Abhimanyu da for giving me this opportunity. I can’t wait to start shooting with Om, Srabanti and Soham da, whom I have been watching for many years.”The comedy flick, bankrolled by Eskay Movies, will go on floors later this month.

title: Men flee village at heart of Monday mayhem as police carry out raids
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, riot,Mob lynch,Chandpur District,bulandshahr,Beena Banerjee
content: CHINGRAVATI/MAHAV (BULANDSHAHR): An erie silence prevailed in Mahav village on Tuesday, a day afer Chingravati police outpost -- 2 km from here -- became an epicentre of violence that led to the death station officer of Syana police station Subodh Kumar and an agitator Sumit Kumar over cow slaughter allegations.Most of the male members have left the village as police continue to raid houses looking for accused named in the FIR. On Monday, inspector Subodh Kumar was killed by a mob as it protested against alleged cow slaughter in the region. An agitator was also killed in the violence after which the mob went on the rampage and indulged in arson and destruction at Chingrawati outpost.WhenTOIvisited the village, most of the women rushed indoors refusing to comment anything on the issue. But one of them, Chetna Devi, confessed that “males had left owing to continuous raids by the police teams in the village.”According to police sources, overnight raids had been conducted in several villages, including Chingravati, Mahav, Chandpur Puthi, Khanpur, Baroli and Naya Baans.Raj Kumar in whose field alleged cow slaughter took place was especially targeted by police, claim villagers. Beena Devi, a former village pradhan and sister-in-law of Raj Kumar, blamed police for the smashed car, chulha, chairs and other items in the household.“A police team comprising 30 men barged into our house at around 1 am and smashed everything in sight when we resisted. Abuses were hurled at us and Raj Kumar’s wife Preeti was beaten up. We are targeted because it was Raj Kumar who had filed police complaint against cow slaughter,” she said. Raj Kumar is absconding as of now. Several other homes have the same complaints.ADG (law and order) Anand Kumar, however, refuted the charges. “We have made six police teams and have also constituted a special investigative team (SIT) to conduct the probe. We have video footages and eyewitnesses’ accounts as primary evidence on the basis of which arrests will be made. Those who are involved in creating the trouble will not be spared and those who are not will not be harassed. There will be no police excesses in this matter and that is why SIT has been formed,” he said.

title: Kejriwal, 6 others let off in 2012 case of rioting outside PM house
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, protest,Prime Minister Manmohan Singh’s house,manmohan singh,kejriwal,india against corruption,coal scam,Arvind Kejriwal
content: NEW DELHI: A Delhi court on Monday discharged the chief minister ArvindKejriwaland six others in a case of alleged rioting in front of the thenPrime Minister Manmohan Singh’s housein 2012.Additional chief metropolitan magistrate Samar Vishal passed the order on discharge after taking into considerations arguments from both sides.The protesters comprised Kejriwal and thenIndia Against Corruptionvolunteers, who were “lathi-charged” and “tear-gassed” by the police when they attempted to gherao Singh’s residence.According to the police chargesheet, certain ‘mischievous elements’ attacked the police with flagstick in which one of the policemen was injured and a barricade with flowerpots damaged.Defense counsel Mohd Irshad had argued that the provision of IPC Section 144 (unlawful assembly) was violative of fundamental rights. He and other lawyers had also argued that the objective of theprotestwas to carry out a peaceful demonstration in front of the residences of the then PM, UPA chairperson and the president of the opposition in connection with thecoal scam. It stressed that the police did not produce any video evidence to show the accused’s complicity.Delhi Police had booked them for the alleged offences under Sections 144 (unlawful assembly), 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object) besides other charges.Besides Kejriwal, the court also discharged Ghan Shyam, Mahesh, Deepak Chhabra, Ranjit Bisht, Amit Kumar Singh and Gautam Kumar Singh.The court had discharged the CM and others in a similar case before and said it was important to balance the citizens’ fundamental rights of peaceful assembly sans arms, besides their right to speech and expression on one hand, and the right of public authorities to maintain law and order on the other.It was then of the view that the prosecution had not claimed that the protesters were up in arms or that they had any criminal intent in their assembly. “It’s also not the case of the prosecution that there was any general problem of traffic or inconvenience caused to the other commuters. Whatever commotion happened, it was due to the use of the force by the police and in consequent retaliation by the protesters,” it had observed.

title: Private buses run riot in Trichy city
keywords: Trichy news, Trichy latest news, Trichy news live, Trichy news today, Today news Trichy, Private buses run riot in Trichy city
content: Trichy: Even as the district administration has fixed speed limit for vehicles in Trichy, it seems that private buses are having a free run in the city putting lives of many in danger. About three years ago, the private city buses were equipped with speed governors, but motorists claimed that absence of a mechanism to check the rash driving of private buses is leading to many accidents in the city. They sought the authorities to check the speed governors in private city buses to ensure the safety of other road users in the city.Sources said that four years ago the district administration made it mandatory for the private buses to fix speed governors. It is said that the Regional Transport Department has been checking speed governors in private buses every time the buses appear to obtain fitness certificate. But, residents and road users in the city refuse to embrace the tall claims. "It is clear that private city buses are racing on city roads, particularly near Palpannai. It is a nightmare for two-wheeler riders to drive along private city buses," H Ghouse Baig, secretary, Consumer Protection Council, Ponmalai branch, said.As many as 147 private buses are operating in the city, and around 90% of them would have fitted speed governors. However, it seems that traffic police and RTO have failed to check regularly the buses to ascertain the proper functioning of the devices. While speed limit has been revised and fixed at 40 km per hour on city roads during night hours and 30 km per hour during daytime and peak hours, commuters said that private buses should be strictly monitored as they were frequently violating the speed limits.D R Dharmarajan, secretary, Trichy District Bus Operators Association, asserted that a majority of the private city buses have fitted speed governors ever since the district administration made it mandatory. While it is claimed that buses with speed governors cannot steer past 40 km per hour, officials with RTO acknowledged that private buses that have speed governors can even speed up beyond 50 km per hour which would very well violate the speed limit fixed by the district administration last month. "We ought to examine the functioning of speed governors in city buses. RTO authorities will be urged to take up the issue," M Sekaran, member of the Road Safety Council told TOI.Many commuters said that stretches between Palpannai and Kattur, Williams Road, Head Post Office to TVS Tollgate, and Subramaniapuram were among the localities the private city buses exceed speed limit. "We will step up the inspection to ensure the presence of speed governors in private buses," an official with city traffic police wing said. title: Delhi court discharges Arvind Kejriwal, 6 others in rioting case
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, rioting case in front of Prime minister's office,Prime Minister of India,manmohan singh,Indian Penal Code,Arvind Kejriwal,Amit Kumar
content: NEW DELHI: A Delhi court on Monday discharged chief ministerArvind Kejriwaland six others in a case of alleged rioting in front of the house of the then Prime MinisterManmohan Singhin 2012.Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Samar Vishal passed the order.According to the prosecution, on August 26, 2012, Kejriwal and others had held a demonstration against coal scam in front of Singh's house and in order to stop them, water cannons were used following which the volunteers became violent.Thereafter, police had fired several rounds of tear gas to drive them off. Certain mischievous elements then attacked the police with flagsticks. The barricade was damaged along with certain plants, the police said.The Delhi Police had booked them for the alleged offences under Sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon) and 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of an offence committed in prosecution of common object) of theIndian Penal Code.Kejriwal and other accused persons were represented through advocate Mohd Irshad in the court.Besides Kejriwal, the court also discharged Ghan Shyam, Mahesh, Deepak Chhabra, Ranjit Bisht,Amit KumarSingh and Gautam Kumar Singh.

title: Bulandshahr riots: ‘Tried to save boss, but I had to run for my own life’
keywords: Lucknow news, Lucknow latest news, Lucknow news live, Lucknow news today, Today news Lucknow, run for life,lynching,died,constable,bullet injuries,bulandshahr
content: LUCKNOW : The driver ofSubodh Kumar Singh+, the UP police inspector who succumbed tobullet injuriesnear a village inBulandshahr, said he made every effort to take his officer to a hospital but indiscriminate firing from a group of men forced him to abandon the jeep and seek his own safety.“My boss was lying unconscious near a boundary wall. I lifted him up and put him inside the police jeep. But moments after I began driving, a group of men started pelting the jeep with stones and began firing at us,” Ram Ashray, the inspector’s driver is heard saying in a video clip.“I had to rush and leave the jeep to save myself,” Ashray added.Cop killed over alleged cow slaughter in UP’s Bulandshahr, video goes viral01:04Ashray was speaking to locals and the media in the video clip. He further said that the men who were firing at them were hiding in sugarcane fields at the site of the incident.The UP police confirmed that an x-ray had shown that Singh haddiedof a bullet injury to his head.UP cop killed in Bulandshahr mob violence was investigation officer of Dadri lynching casePolice inspector Subodh Kumar Singh, 47, who met a violent end during clashes sparked over a cow carcass on Monday in Syana village of Bulandshahr, was also the investigation officer in the 2015 lynching of Mohammad Akhlaq allegedly over possession and consumption of beef at Bisadha village in Greater Noida’s Dadri.The UP government set up a Special Investigation Team (SIT) to probe the incident.“The men began attacking us for the second time today. They were hurling abuses at us and egging on others to hit us,” Ashray says in the clip. Ashray also said that some local people had helped him and his aides rush the injured police inspector to a hospital.“I had two more colleagues, Birender Singh and Subhash, with me at the site of the incident,” Ashray said.

title: Gujarat riots: SC to hear Zakia's plea against clean chit to PM Modi in January
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Zakia Jafri,Narendra Modi,High Court of Gujarat,Ehsan Jafri,2002 Gujarat riots
content: NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Monday deferred till the third week of January the hearing on a plea filed byZakia Jafrichallenging the clean chit given by the special investigation team (SIT) to then Gujarat chief ministerNarendra Modiin connection with the 2002 Godhra riots.Zakia, the wife ofEhsan Jafri, an ex-MP who was killed in one of the worst incidents during the riots, has challenged the Gujarat High Court's October 5, 2017 order rejecting her plea against the SIT's decision.A bench of Justices A M Khanwilkar and Hemant Gupta posted the matter for hearing in the third week of January.

title: A laugh riot for Pune's theatre enthusiasts
keywords: Pune news, Pune latest news, Pune news live, Pune news today, Today news Pune, theatre,play,eka lagnachi pudhchi goshta,Bal Gandharva,Advait Dadarkar

title: 'Big fish' still roaming free: Delhi CM Kejriwal after court upheld conviction of 80 people in 1984 riots
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, Indira Gandhi,Delhi Police,Delhi high court's judgement on 1984 riots,delhi high court,Arvind Kejriwal,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: NEW DELHI: Welcoming theDelhi high court's judgement upholding the conviction of around 80 people for rioting during1984 anti-Sikh riots, chief ministerArvind Kejriwalon Wednesday said the "big fish" are still roaming free and justice has so far not been done to the riot victims even after 34 years.The Delhi high court on Wednesday upheld the conviction of around 80 people and awarded them five-year jail term for rioting, burning houses and violation of curfew during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots."I welcome Delhi high court judgment upholding the conviction of 88 culprits responsible for the murder of hundreds of innocent people in Trilokpuri during 1984 riots. Justice has so far not been done to riot victims even after 34 years. Big fish are still roaming free," he said in a tweet.I welcome Delhi High Court judgment upholding the conviction of 88 culprits responsible for the murder of hundreds… https://t.co/AIQMiFX1zk— Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal)1543401273000After the assassination of the then Prime MinisterIndira Gandhion October 31, 1984, the next couple of days witnessed widespread rioting and killings of Sikhs in the national capital.According to the FIR lodged in connection with the Trilokpuri incident, 95 people had died in the rioting and 100 houses were burnt, said senior advocate H S Phoolka, who has been representing the riot victims in various matters.The convicts had challenged the August 27, 1996 judgement of a Sessions Court which had convicted 88 out of the 107 people arrested on November 2, 1984, for rioting, burning houses and curfew violation in Trilokpuri area of East Delhi.Justice RK Gauba dismissed their 22-year old appeals against the conviction and asked all the convicts to surrender forthwith to undergo the prison term.Of the 88 convicts who moved the high court, several have died during the pendency of their appeals and the case against them has abated, police had earlier said.On November 20, a Delhi court had awarded death penalty to convict Yashpal Singh for killing two men in the 1984 anti-Sikh riots, the first capital punishment in the case. The court had also awarded life term to co-convict Naresh Sherawat in the case. It was the first conviction in the cases reopened by the SIT.TheDelhi Policehad closed the case in 1994 for want of evidence. However, a Special Investigation Team on the riots reopened it.Of the 650 cases registered in connection with anti-Sikh riots in Delhi, 267 were closed as untraced by the Delhi Police. Of these 267 cases, five were later taken up by the CBI. The SIT also scrutinised the records of 18 cancelled cases.The SIT found 60 cases appropriate for further investigation. It filed "untraced report" in 52 cases in the last one-and-a-half years.Out of the eight cases being investigated, charge sheets have been filed in five, and three, in which senior Congress leader Sajjan Kumar is an accused, are pending investigation.

title: Hundreds riot over sackings at Noida Chinese phone unit
keywords: Noida news, Noida latest news, Noida news live, Noida news today, Today news Noida, Xiaomi and Oppo phones,workers of the Hipad Technology India,Noida Mobile phone company workers go on rampage,Mobile phone company workers go on rampage,hundreds of workers go on rampage in Noida,biometrics
content: NOIDA: Hundreds of employees of a Chinese smartphone manufacturing facility here resorted to violence on Thursday after around 200 of them were "sacked without notice", officials said.Around 1,200workers of the Hipad Technology India, which makesXiaomi and Oppo phones, went on a rampage pelting stones at the building and barging into the facility in Sector 63, they said.However, the company had no official response.Police force was deployed at the site even as senior officers, including Superintendent of Police, Noida City, Sudha Singh, reached there to assess the situation.Singh said police were alerted about the violence breaking out at the factory, under Phase 3 police station limits, around 10am and immediately reached the spot."We got to know that several employees had resorted to violence after they were 'sacked' by their office without any notice," she said.Singh said no formal complaint had been lodged by the company till the afternoon, even as police were probing the facts.However, a police official, who did not wish to be named, said three to four people have been picked up for questioning over their alleged involvement in the violence.A source of the company said they had intimidated the vendor - workers' contractor - in advance about the changes."Also, it is clearly mentioned in the terms and conditions of the contract that the company can reduce the number of workers without notice," the source said.The Labour Department officials who reached the unit in the afternoon said it appeared to be a case of "miscommunication" on the company's part."Due to shortage of raw material, the company had asked the vendors to tell these people not to come for work from Monday. But they continued to come to office and the management today barred them from punching in (biometric entry)."The vendor had possibly not informed the workers that is why they kept coming to work which apparently led to this misunderstanding. The office asked them to leave the premises and the workers said they were not informed about the decision and were being sacked that is why they resorted to violence," Assistant Labour Commissioner Harish Chandra Singh told PTI.The vendors were not available at the site for clarification on the issue, Singh added.He said the company claimed that it has engaged a neighbouring firm where it wanted to train these employees, but due to power-related issues that could not happen immediately."The company said they did not directly inform the workers about the training programme but told this to the vendor," Singh said.Meanwhile, a private security guard at the unit described that the morning shift workers had arrived at 8 am for work and within two hours the rampage had begun."They went inside and usually by 8.30am they all set to work on the assembly line. But more than a thousand workers had gathered outside the main building around 9.45am and chaos ensued," the guard said.He also claimed that after the violence several employees fled the building with several mobile phones and other gadgets from the building.

title: Satyendar Jain cleared in rioting case, witnesses fail to identify him
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, Satyendra Kumar Jain,satyendarjain cleared in rioting case,Satyendar,rioting case,rioting,Fail
content: NEW DELHI: A Delhi court on Tuesday acquitted Delhi health ministerSatyendarJain in an alleged case ofriotingbefore the 2013 Delhi assembly election. The court granted relief to Jain and four others, noting that the witnesses cited by the prosecution failed to identify Jain.Jain was arrested by Delhi Police for allegedly rioting and obstructing public servants from discharging their duty during the protest that was held after a reported rape incident. Advocate Irshad, who appeared for Jain, said that the case was filed against Jain and four other protesting members. Jain had to spend two days in jail after his arrest after the FIR was lodged.The lawyer also said that no case property was ever brought before the court. Secondly, additional chief metropolitan magistrate Samar Vishal observed that no public servant appeared before it to prove that he or she was obstructed by Jain from doing official duty. The defense had further argued that Jain was not present at the place of incident as alleged.The witnesses could not identify the damage to the public property, as alleged by the prosecution, the defense said.The police had booked Jain and others in 2013 for various offences punishable under the Indian Penal Code, including under Sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty) and 186 (obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions).

title: Anti-Sikh riots: Sukhbir terms Delhi HC verdict half justice
keywords: Chandigarh news, Chandigarh latest news, Chandigarh news live, Chandigarh news today, Today news Chandigarh, Delhi HC judgememt
content: Chandigarh: Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) president Sukhbir Singh Badal on Wednesday welcomed the Delhi high court judgment, upholding the conviction of 88 accused in the anti-Sikh riots in 1984.Terming the judgment as half justice, he said the conviction was only for rioting, arson and violation of curfew as ordered by a trial court way back in 1996. He blamed the Congress government led by then Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi for ensuring that no case of murder was registered against any person and the FIR was registered for mere arson and rioting only.He said the murderers of 95 Sikhs have not been put on trial yet. He hoped that soon the big sharks too would be in the net of the law and justice would finally prevail. He alleged hordes of Congress workers led by their senior leaders had charged Sikh-dominated Trilokpuri, resulting in brutal murder of 95 innocent people and torching of over 100 houses.Sukhbir said in all, over 3,000 innocent persons were killed in the worst-ever carnage in the history of independent India and people cutting across all religions, countries had condemned this barbaric act.He blamed the tardy investigation for dragging these cases for nearly 34 years after the occurrence of crime. He said, “The real justice would be on the day when the agent provocateurs like Sajjan Kumar and Jagdish Tytler would be convicted and send to gallows. And I am confident that day is not too far.”

title: Cop among 2 killed in mob riots over ‘cow slaughter’ in Bulandshahr
keywords: Meerut news, Meerut latest news, Meerut news live, Meerut news today, Today news Meerut, violence over cow in UP,Uttar Pradesh,police inspector was killed in Bulandshahr,Hindu Yuva Vahini,Bulandshahr district,Aurangabad railway station
content: MEERUT: A police inspector and a youth were killed on Monday as a rampaging mob protesting against alleged cow slaughter in the area torched a police post in west Uttar Pradesh’sBulandshahr districtand clashed with cops.District magistrate Anuj Kumar Jha said the station officer of Syana, where the clashes took place, was killed in the violence. The officer, Subodh Kumar Singh, was shot in the head, Jha said.The protesters also set several vehicles on fire and pelted stones at cops, which led the police to open fire, resulting in the death of an agitator, identified as Sumit, 18, of gunshot wounds.File photo of deceased police inspector, Subodh KumarThe area remains tense following the violence that continued for nearly three hours. The state government has deployed additional police, including over 1,000 personnel of anti-riot forces, and ordered multiple probes, including one by a special investigation team led by additional director general of police (intelligence), another by ADG (technical) and a magisterial inquiry.According to sources, trouble started with locals from Mahav village finding carcasses of cows in a nearby forest. Led by members of Hindu outfits, agitators loaded the carcasses on a tractor and placed these near the Chingrawati police outpost on Syana-Garh highway near Bulandshahr city, approximately 150 km from the national capital.“This morning, carcasses of cows were found dumped in a forest area outside the village. Activists of right-wing organisations soon gathered at the spot and alleged that people of a particular community were indulging in cow slaughter,” ADG (law and order) Anand Kumar said.Angry villagers and members of various Hindu groups raised slogans against the police administration and blocked the Bulandshahr-Garh state highway.Expressing grief over the incident, chief minister Yogi Adityanath, who is away campaigning in Rajasthan, said strict action will be taken against the guilty after the probe reports are received. He also said financial assistance would be extended to victims of the violence.The ADG (law and order) claimed that policemen retaliated with a lathi-charge after the violent mob attacked them. According to witnesses, the violent mob soon overpowered the police force. They set the Chingrawati police outpost on fire as well as several vehicles in the premises. The mob also targeted police vans and set several motorcycles on fire.In the ensuing violence, Syana SO Subodh Kumar Singh was killed after a bullet hit him near his left eyebrow and remained stuck in his skull. Sumit, an 18-year-old protester and a resident of Chingrawti village, sustained bullet injuries and was rushed to Meerut, where he succumbed to his injuries. Several policemen and agitators have sustained injuries in varying degrees and have been admitted in nearby hospitals.The ADG said that security has been bolstered in the area with 500 personnel of Rapid Action Force and 600 personnel of Provincial Armed Constabulary. Senior police and administrative officials, including ADG (Meerut zone) Prashant Kumar and divisional commissioner Anita Meshram, are camping at the spot.In a statement, CM Yogi said that ADG (technical) SB Shirodkar has been asked to submit a detailed report on the incident in two days. Based on the findings of the report, strict action will be taken against people behind the incident, he said.Read this story in Marathi

title: 1984 anti-Sikh riots: Delhi high court upholds conviction of 88 people
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Trilokpuri,trial court,Jail,Indira Gandhi,delhi high court,conviction,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: NEW DELHI: TheDelhi high courton Wednesday upheld theconvictionof 88 people by thetrial courtin connection with the1984 anti-Sikh riotsin east Delhi'sTrilokpuriarea, ANI reported.The high court while dismissing the petitions of these 88 people asked them to surrender within four weeks.The convicts have been sentenced to five years injail. The HC upheld their conviction for burning houses and curfew violation during the 1984 riots.1984 anti-Sikh riots: Death penalty for one convict; life imprisonment for anotherA Delhi court on Tuesday awarded death penalty to convict Yashpal Singh for his role in the 1984 anti-Sikh riots and sentenced another convict, Naresh Sehrawat, to life imprisonment. The verdict was pronounced in Tihar jail due to security concerns.On November 20, a Delhi court awarded death penalty to convict Yashpal Singh and ordered life imprisonment to another, Naresh Sherawat, for killing of two men during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots.In the first verdict after the riots-related cases were reopened by a Special Investigation Team (SIT) in 2015, the court held that Singh's offence fell under the "rarest of rare" category warranting the death penalty. The Delhi Police had closed this case in 1994 for want of evidence.The SIT is investigating nearly 60 cases related to the riots, while it has filed "untraced report" in 52 cases.The riots had taken place after the assassination of the then Prime MinisterIndira Gandhileaving nearly 3,000 people dead.(With agency inputs)

title: SC has relied on sealed cover proceedings in several cases – Gujarat riots, 2G, coal scam, CBI & Rafale
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Supreme Court,SC,Rafale deal,coal scam,2G scam
content: To prevent further damage to the CBI’s public image, already sullied by incessant mudslinging between CBI director Alok Verma and his deputy Rakesh Asthana, theSupreme Courthad resorted to ‘sealed cover proceedings’ while asking all parties to maintain strict confidentiality.After a bench led by CJI Ranjan Gogoi ordered ‘strict confidentiality’, three CBI officers had filed applications challenging their transfers out of Delhi immediately after the Centre sent both Verma and Asthana on leave.The last application was by an IPS officer with 18 years experience. He did little justice to his experience as a police officer by relying on ‘unverified’ statement of Hyderabad-based businessman Sathish Babu Sana to make ‘shocking’ allegations against Asthana, the CVC, the NSA, a Union minister, the law secretary and a RAW special secretary.The real facts behind these ‘shocking’ allegations need to be found out. We also must know what impelled the IPS officer to level these allegations when theSCthrough ‘sealed cover proceedings’ was scrutinising the CVC report’s which contained “not so complimentary and very uncomplimentary’ remarks against Verma.But the ‘sealed cover proceedings’ appears to have disturbed some, who are questioning its efficacy. The same people have expressed similar doubts over sealed cover proceedings adopted by the SC in scrutinising theRafale deal. Since 2000, ‘sealed cover’ proceedings have been adopted by the SC in Gujarat riot cases, the 2G spectrum allocation scam and the coal block allocation scam.In post-Godhra riots cases, R K Raghavan headed SIT had filed several sealed cover status reports before the SC. As the SC was gunning for the Gujarat government then headed by Narendra Modi, Raghavan was hailed as an independent investigator by social activists and their activist lawyers as media reported the summary of the contents of almost every SIT report.One SIT report unfortunately talked about an activist peddling exaggerated stories about riot victims as also tutoring witnesses. Reporting of this SIT report caused much discomfort. The activists’ lawyer vociferously and repeatedly pleaded with the SC to initiate contempt proceedings against the reporter for revealing details of the ‘sealed cover’ report.In arbitrary allocation of 2G spectrum by UPA government in 2008, the SC had routinely scrutinised ‘sealed cover’ CBI probe status reports. No one questioned the efficacy of such proceedings then.The SC yet again adopted ‘sealed cover’ proceedings to monitor CBI probe into coal block allocations under the UPA regime. The then PM too has been made an accused in the case, though the trial against him has been stayed since 2015 by the SC.Before the ex-PM was made an accused, the CBI made a startling admission on April 30, 2013 — probe status reports, prior to submission to the SC, were vetted by then law minister and two joint secretary level officers, one in the PMO and the other in the coal ministry.On May 8, 2013, the SC recorded, “The draft status report was shared with the law minister, law officers and two joint secretary level officers and at their instance some changes were made. Some of the changes made in these draft status reports are significant.” Changes related to CBI’s PE2, which was on alleged irregularities in coal block allocations during 2006-09, when the ex-PM held the coal portfolio.Those who had subjugated the CBI director, illegally vetted and audaciously made vital changes in the probe status report are now vociferous while shedding crocodile tears for the danger to the CBI’s autonomy. We hope there will be constructive criticism of a decision by the court rather than nitpicking over ‘sealed cover proceedings’.A majority of politicians and activists behave according to the season and circumstances. Very few rise above the surroundings to work for greater common good. It reminds us of a small story: Once a king dreamt of an owl flapping around his throne. None in the durbar could decipher the dream. The king announced a handsome reward of 10 gold coins. A long distance away, a farmer resting under a tree was day-dreaming of the reward. A bird on the tree told the farmer she would share the dream’s meaning if he agreed to share the reward. Farmer agreed. Bird said betrayal and treachery rules the roost in the kingdom. The farmer told the king what the dream meant. The king found it in sync with intelligence reports. The farmer’s happiness fizzled out as soon as he neared home as the thought of giving the bird five gold coins was gnawing him. He took an alternative road home.A year later, the king saw another dream. A knife revolving around his throne. He sent for the farmer, who ran straight to the bird, apologised for betraying her the last time, and promised to share the booty this time. The bird said the dream meant violence would erupt in the kingdom. Satisfied with the meaning of the dream, the king gave 20 gold coins to the farmer. The man was sadder this time and working himself into a fury by repeatedly asking – what will a bird do with 10 gold coins? While heading home, he picked up a stone. As he neared the tree and the moment the bird asked for her share, the man aimed the stone at her. The bird flew away.Next year, the king dreamt of a dove flying around his throne and again sent for the man, who ran to the tree, and profusely apologised for his treacherous and violent actions in the past. In bargain for same promise to share the reward, the bird said this time there is peace in the kingdom and the king could take up welfare works for citizens. A happy king rewarded the farmer with 50 gold coins. The man went straight to the tree, gave all the gold coins to the bird and sought forgiveness.The bird smiled and said gold coins were of no use to her. But few men can rise above the surroundings and prevailing atmosphere to behave like real men, she said and told the farmer to strive to be a real man who remains uninfluenced by the atmosphere of distrust and conspiracy. Prior to every election, politicians across the political landscape behave alike and trade charges against each other with the sole aim of winning votes. We hope times will change.

title: Telangana assembly elections 2018: KCR reads riot act, says Modi is communal
keywords: Hyderabad news, Hyderabad latest news, Hyderabad news live, Hyderabad news today, Today news Hyderabad, Telugu Desam Party,telangana assembly polls 2018,Telangana Assembly Elections 2018,Telangana,N. Chandrababu Naidu
content: HYDERABAD: TRS president K Chandrasekhar Rao demolished rumours of a hush-hush pact with BJP by launching a no-holds barred attack on PM Narendra Modi and called him "communal". Modi not only kept the hike in quota for Muslims in abeyance, but also sat on the Scheduled Tribes (STs) quota despite the assembly passing two resolutions and sending it for Central nod two years ago, he said. The state government had proposed 12% reservations for Muslims and 10% for STs."KCR is stubborn and won't abandon issues. Like I fought for statehood, I will also fight for reservations for minorities and STs," he said at a public meeting at Manukota in Mahbubabad assembly constituency, a ST reserved segment, on Friday.For the first time in recent past, KCR spoke on national politics and the federal front, an idea floated by him. "Both Congress and BJP at the Centre are same and try to dominate state governments. There should be a federal government with non-BJP and non-Congress parties at the Centre. TRS will aim to dictate terms to Centre after Lok Sabha elections," he said.KCR attacked TDP chief Chandrababu Naidu in rallies at Narasampet, Dornakal, Suryapet, Mahbubabad and Janagaon. Congress is bringing Naidu again to Telangana. "It is a strategy where the knife is from AP, but being used byTelanganaCongress leaders to stab Telangana people," he said and added Naidu wrote letters to the Centre against irrigation projects in Telangana and tried to stop bifurcation of high court. "I had done my bit by packing him out of Telangana and now it is your turn to reject him and the grand alliance," he said. He also recalled remarks by Congress candidate from Mahbubabad Balaram Naik, who threatened Telangana would be merged with AP if Congress is not voted to power.At each public meeting, he urged people to compare earlier governments and TRS rule during in past four-and-half years. "Many political parties come and make promises during elections. But do not go by false promises. You (people) should compare what had been done by Congress and TDP in past 58 years and TRS in four-and-half years and vote," he said.KCR said thandas have been converted into gram panchayats and about 3,500 sarpanches from STs would be elected in gram panchayats polls. He also assured them steps will be taken within six months after the formation of second TRS government to ensure that forest land which are under the possession of tribals remains with them.

title: BJP targets Congress over 1984 riots

content: NEW DELHI: BJP on Wednesday accused Congress of working to deny justice to the victims of1984 anti-Sikh riotsand also targetedKamal Nath, the opposition party’s chief in poll-boundMadhya Pradesh, saying he was removed as the party’s in-charge for the Punjab assembly polls following protests by Sikhs. A day after a Delhi court awarded death sentence to an accused and life imprisonment to another in a 1984 riots case, senior BJP leader and Union ministerRavi Shankar Prasadsaid the probe carried out by a Special Investigation Team set up by the Centre had led to the sentencing.“We (BJP) are very satisfied,” the minister said about his party’s stand on the verdict and added that people needed to be told that Congress had tried to ensure that the Sikh victims did not get justice. The opposition party did it to save its own people,” he alleged.

title: 1984 anti-Sikh riots case: How a team of officers and lawyers put all pieces together
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, urdu,special investigation team,Punjab (region),linguistics,jalandhar,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: NEW DELHI: The judgment is out. Death penalty for one, and life term for the other. Behind the scenes of its maiden case related to 1984 Sikh carnage, however, is aspecial investigation team(SIT) and a bunch of lawyers, who put all the scattered pieces of this jigsaw together, piece after piece. The team started from scratch after the SIT was appointed in 2015 hoping to build a watertight case. To do it, the team exercised unconventional ways to gather both evidence and witnesses.The delay of over 30 years had already proved detrimental for the investigation as several witnesses had moved out of India while many others got displaced within the country. For one such witness, who was traced to the US, the team used Skype to recorded his statement. An another witness was found to be living in Italy. He came down from Italy to testify. Both witnesses proved crucial for the case. "This was unprecedented. But the unique nature of the case required unusual methods of evidence gathering," says a source privy to the investigation.The year 1984 in this part of the country saw police's diary entries and other related documents being written inUrduand Gurukumukhi. The team took help of someone from its own department. An old hand, adept inlinguistics, the expert interpreted the texts that were put in compact discs. The case's prosecutor, advocate SK Kain says, "The investigation was not easy but we tried to put forth the best that we had in evidence and testimonies." According to him, the prosecution sought death penalty for the nature of crime that was committed. The carnage, he says, had left close to 3,000 dead in Delhi alone. "It still remains a deep scar in psyche of people. It was essential for the court to take into consideration the heinous nature of crime," he adds.Speaking of hurdles, tracing old police records and then decoding them did not come easy. The pages had turned yellow, brittle and blotted with the passage of time. To see the texts clearly, the officials used magnifying glasses. The challenge was to preserve the files and papers for the the pages broke easily even on turning gently. Read, translate and preserve -- was the team's momentary goal.The investigators, on the other hand, comprised 10 inspectors, four ACPs and support staff along with lawyers, who had to scan 650 files with over 10,000 pages and find clinching evidence to build a formidable case.The team took one year alone to trace the old case diaries. When traced, the 30 year old writings had turned illegible. That's when the magnifying glasses came in handy. The team also faced logistical and infrastructural issues initially, but insisted on moving ahead with the investigation.When it came to tracing victim families, a team of officers was sent to Punjab in 2016, while the remaining officials recorded statements of witnesses. "One witness came all the way from Italy to depose. He is the bother of one of the deceased Avtar Singh," says the source.The biggest hurdle came in form of uncooperative witnesses. Convincing them took depose in court required tremendous persuasion. The officers were bent on getting victims on board for the case was largely based on testimony for the absence of medical evidence over the years. "Also the topography of the place of incident had changed. It was difficult to locate victim families and witnesses. Passing of over 30 years also meant no medical records. The team collected whatever they could find and began a long- arduous journey of investigation," the source says.The team traveled toJalandhar's hinterland to trace the first witnesses. Though the team managed to trace the witnesses, it faced their ire. "Having faced injustice over the years, the victims did not want cooperative and depose in the case," the source adds. The team pacified the witnesses and promised them a fair and timely investigation. The unsurprising hostility paved for renewed support.For a watertight case, the team had to work almost 14 hours day, seven days a week. Once through with hundreds of hours in investigation, the team was confident enough to bring it to a logical conclusion. And delivering on its promise, it convinced the court to convict the two accused men essentially on the basis of witness testimonies. The court's appreciation was apparent when it said the investigating was present in court "on every date".

title: BJP attacks Congress over anti-Sikh riots after court verdict
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Ranganath Misra,Narendra Modi,manmohan singh,Indira Gandhi,Gujarat,Atal Bihari Vajpayee,Abhishek Singhvi
content: NEW DELHI: The BJP accused the Congress on Wednesday of working to deny justice to the 1984 anti-Sikh riots victims and also targeted Kamal Nath, the opposition party's chief in poll-bound Madhya Pradesh, saying he was removed as the party's in-charge for the Punjab Assembly polls following protests by Sikhs.A day after a Delhi court awarded death sentence to an accused and life imprisonment to another in a 1984 anti-Sikh riots case, senior Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) leader Ravi Shankar Prasad said the probe carried out by a Special Investigation Team (SIT) set up by theNarendra Modigovernment led to the sentencing."We (BJP) are very satisfied," the Union minister told reporters about his party's stand on the verdict and added that people needed to be told that the Congress had, during its rule, tried to ensure that the Sikh riot victims did not get justice.The opposition party did it to save its own people, Prasad alleged.There was no reaction to the court verdict from the Congress Wednesday, but its spokesperson Abhishek Manu Singhvi had welcomed it Tuesday."The Congress's stand is clear. This is a legal process, a legal process which must be allowed to work out its course and we are very proud, happy and fortunate that it is taking its course," Singhvi had told reporters.Tuesday's court verdict gave some sort of a balm to those suffering for over 30-35 years, Prasad said.The law minister said his party wanted to assure the Sikhs, especially those whose families had suffered, that the SIT would probe the cases honestly, without any undue outside interference, and take action against the guilty.Targeting Nath, who has been accused by some Sikh bodies of having links to the riots, Prasad noted that the Congress had removed him as its in-charge for the Punjab polls last year following protests by people.The Congress should answer as to why was Nath removed, he said.Nath had in the past rejected the charges against him and said he had no links with the 1984 anti-Sikhs riots, following the assassination of the then prime ministerIndira Gandhiby her Sikh bodyguards.Prasad also pointed out that Rajiv Gandhi, who succeeded his mother Indira as the prime minister, had said the earth shook when a big tree fell and alleged that the Congress had condoned the organised violence against Sikhs.Former prime ministerManmohan Singhmight have apologised for the riots, but the opposition party should answer if it had disassociated itself from Rajiv Gandhi's comments, the BJP leader said, adding that the remarks had rubbed salt into the wounds of the riot victims.He also asked the Congress to answer why no action was taken against the culprits during its over-two-decades-long rule following the riots.Prasad claimed that the previous Congress governments had set up several committees to probe the riots only to delay justice, adding that in some cases, the opposition party never acted on the reports of those panels.TheAtal Bihari Vajpayeegovernment had constituted the Nanavati Commission, which had said the riots were organised and had also blamed the police, he said.The report of the commission was submitted when the Congress came to power in 2004 and its government took no action, Prasad claimed.He also referred to a commission headed by former chief justice of IndiaRanganath Misra, whose report had largely exonerated the police and claimed that the riots were not a case of organised violence.Noting that the Congress had nominated Misra, now deceased, to the Rajya Sabha in 1998, Prasad alleged that it was a "reward" for his report.To a query about other riots, including those inGujaratin 2002, Prasad said there were convictions in many of the Gujarat riots cases and added that a Supreme Court-monitored SIT had questioned Prime Minister Modi, who was the chief minister of the state then, for three days and given him a clean chit.

title: It's a start, says witness
keywords: Amritsar news, Amritsar latest news, Amritsar news live, Amritsar news today, Today news Amritsar, riots,Palam,amritsar,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: AMRITSAR: A prime witness in the 1984 anti-Sikhriotshas said that the real culprits who orchestrated the violence in Delhi are still out and the two men who have been handed down punishments, including the death penalty, for the mass killings have just been their foot soldiers.When the riots broke out in Delhi at the start of November that year, Jagdish Kaur lost her teenaged son, three brothers and husband.Sitting at her home in Amritsar, where she moved to in December 1984, Kaur said, "Those awarded sentences are nothing but foot soldiers who followed the orders of their masters, who are still out and free," said Jagdish, who claims to be witness to Congress leader Sajjan Kumar's role in the riots atPalamColony in South-West Delhi.Of the two convicts, Yashpal Singh was given the death penalty for the riots, while Naresh Sehrawat was sentenced to life term. The court also imposed a fine of Rs 35 lakh on each of them.Jagdish called the duo's conviction and sentencing "a beginning". "The big fish are still enjoying all privileges and are still immune to law," she said.At the time of the riots, Jagdish had managed to save her three daughters and five-year-old son by taking them to the house of one of her neighbour.She arrived in Amritsar in December 1984 and worked menial jobs to survive.

title: Anti-Sikh riots of 1984: Wounds from 34 years ago are raw as ever
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, Sikh,riots,Deaths,Crime
content: NEW DELHI: Sheela Kaur sported a wry smile as her neighbour Banto Kaur informed her about the first conviction in the cases related to the anti-Sikhriotsof 1984. “Were they from Sultanpuri?” Sheela asked, wondering if the men, one of whom got death, the other life imprisonment on Tuesday, were involved in the killing of six family members in Sultanpuri. “I saw local Congress leaders leading and instigating the mobs not to spare any Sikh,” alleged Sheela, 55, who now lives with her son in west Delhi’s Tilak Vihar Colony. “To finally hear that some of the killers have been convicted is a small victory. We now wait for the main conspirators to be punished.”On a momentous day in the history of the riot litigations, many others like Sheela recalled the horrors and the glacial pace of justice. Sundri Kaur, 60, lost her husband Bhagwan Singh as also her brother-in-law and father-in-law in Sultanpuri’s C Block. “My husband was an autorickshaw driver. On November 1, he left home never to return. We don’t even know what fate he met,” Sundri said. “His auto was found at Trilokpuri police station 15 days later.”Sundri remembered with bitterness how she provided information in court about the people leading the rioters and supplying them fuel for arson, but “the opposition lawyers asked me about what I ate that day.” Like her, Banto Kaur claimed that she did not even get the chance to have a case registered against the murder of her father-in-law and brother-in-law.“We escaped from Sultanpuri and hid in Rani Bagh,” Banto said. “I saved my eight-year-old son by making him dress like a girl.” Filled with a new courage after the two convictions, Banto added, “Whether the Sikh victim is from Mahipalpur, Trilokpuri or Sultanpuri, we will fight for them and bring the main conspirators to justice.” Sundri and Banto rued that in trying to fight the cases and make ends meet, they couldn’t give much time to their growing sons.Gurinder Singh, whose father and uncle were killed in Mangolpuri, has spent more than two decades in the courts.Born a month after the riots, he learnt about the manner of his father’s death and has been protesting outside Delhi high court with a plaque demanding justice. “Today, we got some hope. But these are small fish. The big ones need to be brought to book,” he declared.Like Gurinder, Ganga Kaur, who was four at the time of the riots, said that the verdict has filled her with hope. Her family lost 11 members in Trilokpuri.“My father was lynched outside his warehouse while my grandfather was killed inside the gurdwara. We were well-off then, but suffered a lot after that. Justice is long overdue to us,” said Ganga.

title: Man gets death for 1984 riots in case reopened after 21 years
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Yashpal,Tihar jail,Sikh riots case,Sikh,riots,1984 Sikh riots case,1984 Sikh riots,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: NEW DELHI: Almost exactly 34 years after anti-Sikhriotsshook Delhi, a city court, in a “rarest-of-rare” judgment on Tuesday, sentenced a 55-year-old man to death and sent another to prison for life after having held them guilty last week of killing two Sikh youths and other heinous crimes during the 1984 violence.“The case of this kind breaks the entire fabric, trust and harmony amongst communities, thereby severely affecting the assimilation of different religious and social groups,” additional sessions judge Ajay Pandey observed.In an unprecedented move, the order sentencingYashpalSingh to death and Naresh Sehrawat to life imprisonment, was pronounced insideTihar Jaildue to security concerns. Earlier, the court had held the duo held guilty of killing Hardev Singh, who was then 24 years old, and Avtar Singh, 26. Three other men, Sangat Singh, Kuldeep Singh and Surjeet Singh, were injured in the mob attack.“The culpability of both convicts falls within the category of rarest of rare cases,” the judge held, adding that the both men were influential neighbours of the victims. They committed the “horrendous” crime of murder and loot to eliminate the victims without any provocation, merely on the basis of the latter’s faith, community and religion.This was the first conviction secured by the Supreme Court-appointed special investigation team (SIT), formed in 2015 to reopen Sikh carnage cases. The court also imposed fines of Rs 35 lakh each on the convicts.The 1984 riots had led the Sikh community being “severely prejudiced” with regard to their life and livelihood, and had led to large scale migration, the judge said.

title: We need action against politicians and police officers, says 1984 riot survivors
keywords: Chandigarh news, Chandigarh latest news, Chandigarh news live, Chandigarh news today, Today news Chandigarh, Riot survivors,Jamalpur District,Etawah,Central Reserve Police Force,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: LUDHIANA: Welcoming the first death penalty to a convict in a1984 anti-Sikh riotscase, the survivors living in Ludhiana say that they are waiting for punishment for “bigger fish” — politicians and police officers.“We lived in Mangolpuri and had a refrigerator parts factory in Kirti Nagar. During the riots, not only were my brothers-in-law, 35-year-old Swaroop Singh and 30-year-old Vikramjeet Singh, brutally murdered by mobs, my husband Pratap Singh was also badly injured with sharp-edged weapons. After many days, we found him alive in a hospital. I had to leave Delhi with a seriously-injured husband. He could never even stand after that. Leaving behind a booming business, we started from scrap in Ludhiana and raised my four children, including a daughter who was born after the riots,” said 50-year-old Gurdeep Kaur, who lives in CRPF colony in Dugri which houses around 400 families of the 1984riot survivors.“We could hardly live after the riots and now that judgment has come in two cases, we feel that this should just be the start. We want that big politicians and police officers involved in the riots should be punished. This can be achieved only through fast-track courts so that speedy justice is done to us,” she added.Many victims say that they feel that they have got a small reprieve but are waiting for the day politicians and police officers are punished for the horrific crimes.“The 1984 riots were the worst form of crime against humans. The recent judgments have come as a hope that a day will come when we will see the big fish are punished. This will not end the sufferings of victims, but will at least apply a balm to their wounds,” said Surjeet Singh, president of the 1984 victims’ association in Ludhiana whose family escaped from riots inEtawah. He added that there are 245 cases that need to be reopened.Ludhiana has roughly about 8,000 families of the 1984 riot victims who live in CRPF colony in Dugri, LIG and MIG flats in the same area, Jamalpur, Haibowal and other areas.Many victims feel that justice after 34 years is too little and too late. “It is perhaps shocking that two persons were punished 34 years after riots. I don’t know whether it is justice to us or not, but it has taken a long time. We feel that it is just eyewash and is to save big fish by punishing small ones. This is being done to cool down our tempers,” said 38-year-old Lakhwinder Singh, who lives at Tajpur road and owns a furniture shop. “We had to sell our house in Guru Angad Nagar in Old Delhi at throwaway price (around Rs 1.5 lakh for a property of around Rs 6 lakh) after surviving the riots and shifted to Ludhiana.”

title: Sikh leaders welcome death penalty to 1984 riots case convict
keywords: India, India news, India news today, Today news, Google news, Breaking news, Tihar jail,shiromani akali dal,Sajjan Kumar,Patiala House Courts Complex,aam aadmi party,1984 anti-Sikh riots
content: NEW DELHI: Sikh leaders cutting across party lines have welcomed the decision of a court to award death penalty to one of the convicts in a1984 anti-Sikh riotscase, and vowed to continue their fight till each and every victim gets justice.A Delhi court on Tuesday awarded death penalty to convict Yashpal Singh for killing two men in the 1984 anti-Sikh riots, the first capital punishment in the case.Additional Sessions Judge Ajay Pandey also awarded life term to co-convict Naresh Sherawat in the case.Akali Dal leader Manjinder Singh Sirsa said they will challenge the life sentence of Sherawat and ensure that even he gets "hanged for his crimes"."We are satisfied with the judgement but we will keep on fighting and challenge the life sentence of one accused and ensure that even he gets "hanged for his crimes," he told PTI.He also said that the judgement has given witnesses a very big boost and after 34 years they finally got justice.Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee chief and Akali Dal leader Manjit Singh G K said the judgement will encourage other victims to come forward."Other culprits who were hiding behind the Z plus security would be nailed down," he said.Sardar R P Singh, National Secretary of BJP, welcomed the decision and urged the apex court to immediately notify the name of third member of the Special Investigation Team formed to monitor further probe into anti-Sikh riots cases of 1984 mainly in Delhi and other states.Aam Aadmi Party(AAP) leader HS Phoolka said it was a great judgement and now the Sikh leaders are quite hopeful that in other cases also the victims would get justice.A Sikh survivor called the judgement "a start", saying the fight will continue till they get "complete justice" and bring all perpetuators to justice.The Tuesday's verdict was pronounced in theTihar Jaildue to security concerns, and attack on one of the convicts on November 15 in the premises of Patiala House Courts moments after a court reserved its order on the quantum of punishment to be awarded to the accused.On November 14, the court had convicted Singh and Sherawat for killing two men here during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots -- the first conviction in the cases reopened by the SIT.The Delhi Police had closed the case in 1994 for want of evidence. However, a Special Investigation Team on the riots reopened it.Of the 650 cases registered in connection with anti-Sikh riots in Delhi, 267 were closed as untraced by the Delhi Police. Of these 267 cases, five were later taken up by the CBI. The SIT also scrutinised the records of 18 cancelled cases.The SIT found 60 cases appropriate for further investigation. It filed "untraced report" in 52 cases in the last one-and-a-half years.Out of the eight cases being investigated, charge sheets have been filed in five and three, in which senior Congress leaderSajjan Kumaris an accused, are pending investigation.

title: Trial by fire: Doors opened for other victims to claim justice
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, victims,Sikh,riots,fire,anti-sikh
content: NEW DELHI: With the first death penalty ever awarded in a 1984 anti-Sikhriotstrial, the quest for justice forvictimspending before trial court and the Delhi high court has received a big boost.After Tuesday’s sentencing, all eyes will now be on the HC, where appeals challenging acquittal of former Congress MP Sajjan Kumar are pending.Recently, after conducting day to day hearings into the appeals that had been pending since 2014, the bench reserved for orders the appeals filed by the CBI, riots victims and men convicted by the trial court in the case that relates to the murder of five Sikh members of a family in Delhi Cantonment’s Raj Nagar on November 1, 1984, after the assassination of the then Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.Former Congress councillor Balwan Khokhar, a retired naval officer Captain Bhagmal, Girdhari Lal and two others were held guilty in the case by the trial court that had acquitted Sajjan Kumar. It had awarded life term to Khokhar, Bhagmal and Girdhari Lal and a three-year jail term to two others — former MLA Mahender Yadav and Kishan Khokhar — all of whom have challenged their conviction and sentencing by the trial court in May 2013.Assailing Kumar’s acquittal, the CBI has alleged that the accused persons were engaged in “a planned communal riot” and “religious cleansing”. The case relating to Delhi Cantonment is one of the four cases reopened on the recommendation of Justice Nanavati Commission in 2005. The panel had zeroed in on four of the 241 cases closed by Delhi Police and handed these over to the CBI.Separately, another HC bench had last year reopened five other cases related to theanti-Sikhriots on the ground that a trial court judgment of 1986 acquitting the accused was wrong, since neither the witnesses nor the complainants in these cases were examined properly by the trial court. HC had ordered fresh probe against them noting that they faced allegations of “horrifying crimes against humanity.”Tuesday’s verdict has come due to the prosecution by the Special Investigating Team (SIT) that was set up on February 12, 2015 by the Centre following a recommendation by the home ministry-appointed Justice G P Mathur committee. The three-member SIT comprises two inspector general rank IPS officers and a judicial officer with a mandate to investigate/re-investigate 1984 riots cases “and to take all such measures under the law for a thorough investigation of the criminal cases and to file the chargesheet against the accused in the proper court where after investigation sufficient evidence was found available.”

title: 1984 anti-Sikh riots: Sikh leaders hail court verdict, but say their fight is far from over
keywords: Delhi news, Delhi latest news, Delhi news live, Delhi news today, Today news Delhi, verdict,Sikh,riots,leaders,hail
content: NEW DELHI: Cutting across party lines, Sikh leaders on Tuesday welcomed the sentencing of Yashpal Singh (55) and Naresh Sehrawat (68) for killing two men in southwest Delhi’s Mahipalpur in the 1984 anti-Sikhriots. They expressed the hope that the other accused will also be brought to justice soon.Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee president Manjit Singh GK said the conviction was possible only after the special investigative team formed by the Centre reopened the cases.“For 34 years, we have been fighting against the wall. Eleven commissions and committees were formed during this period, 587 FIRs registered and victims and witnesses threatened. Today’s sentencing has really motivated us and I am sure it will give sleepless nights to Jagdish Tytler and Sajjan Kumar,” said GK.He added that the sentencing would inspire a number of witnesses and victims, who had been intimated by the perpetrators, to come out in the open and speak against several others whose role in the attack had not been exposed yet.Former Delhi MLA and BJP national secretary RP Singh said it was a long-awaited decision by the court. “The only concern is that the SC-appointed SIT, which was supposed to submit its report within two months, has not even started working even after eight months of formation, as the name of the third member has not been notified,” Singh said.Senior advocate and the face of the legal struggle of Sikh victims, HS Phoolka, said it was a great judgment and the Sikhleaderswere quite hopeful that in other cases, too, the victims would get justice. “It is a great achievement and will give hope to victims and courage to witnesses to come forward,” Phoolka said.Shiromani Akali Dal (Delhi) secretary general Harvinder Singh Sarna echoed Phoolka’s sentiments and said there was hope that other cases would also be heard and the perpetrators sentenced. “People’s trust in the judiciary has increased tremendously with this judgment,” Sarna said.Former Delhi MLA and Congress leader Arvinder Singh Lovely said his party always believed that the guilty should be punished. “It has been the Congress’ firm stance that the victims should get justice fast. In fact, those who play politics on the riots are reason why justice got delayed,” Lovely said.Rajouri Garden MLA Manjinder Singh Sirsa said he would soon move court demanding death sentence to Sehrawat. “He should have also been awarded death sentence,” Sirsa said.
